awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award will create a rigorous mathematical framework for analysis of the ways in which animals propel themselves through the world, with the goal of designing bio-inspired robots that approach and surpass the capabilities of natural systems. For example, understanding how the frictional properties of snake scales helps the animal move through mud, could lead to the design of smart skins and propulsive gaits for snake-like robotic systems in hazardous terrain. In particular, this project will use powerful geometric techniques to study the locomotion of systems that are currently poorly understood, like flexible and continuously deformable soft robots, or of movements in which the system makes intermittent contact with the ground. The outcomes of this research will greatly advance the design of innovative robots, especially soft robots. Broader impacts of this work will include increased penetration of geometric methods into the broader community of non-mathematicians, facilitated by accessible examples from animal locomotion, and by a textbook and accompanying visualization software.

When systems have joint limits (i.e., they have limbs instead of wheels or propellers), their ability to locomote depends on how effectively they can change their interaction with the environments at different points in a gait cycle. When these interactions are first-order constraints and they change smoothly with the system's shape, locomotive effectiveness can be characterized via a Lie bracket (a structure closely related to the curl of a vector field). This project seeks to extend this concept to include direction-dependent effects (e.g., friction from backwards-pointing spines or bristles), second order dynamics (e.g., elastic tails or wings in air), infinite-dimensional systems, and hybrid systems (e.g. walkers that can lift their feet from the ground. Specific systems that will be made accessible to geometric analysis by this project include, 1) systems with many shape variables, whose curvature is a high-dimensional structure; 2) hybrid systems, which have "corners" in their dynamic curvature; 3) ratcheting systems, whose reaction forces depend on the sign of the relative motion; 4) elastic systems, whose gait cycles partially emerge from their passive dynamics; and 5) gliding systems, whose gait effectiveness is better characterized by momentum transfer than by displacement induced.

por.por_cntn:
Animals and robots that crawl or walk are more complicated to understand and control than are car-like systems that role on wheels. A major part of this complication is that limb and body joints are limited in how far they can bend, whereas a car's wheels can roll without limit. Additionally, the mapping from car wheel motion to chassis motion tends to be a constant relationship based on the wheel not slipping or sliding across the ground, whereas the equivalent mapping for a crawling or walking robot typically depends on the current angles of the limb and body joints, and may also involve some or all contacts sliding against the ground.

Despite these complications, past work from others and ourselves has shown that for many systems there is a strong geometric relationship between cyclic motions in the limb and body joints and the net position change they produce: The net change in position is given by the extent to which moving each joint redirects the motion of the other joint, together with the area the joint oscillations trace out.

The goals of this project were to expand the set of scenarios to which these geometric rules could be applied and to make it easier for engineers and biologists to use these tools.

To this end, we

1. Generalized our existing geometric framework so that it could handle systems with more than two limb or body joints, predicting and illustrating how the interactions between each pair of oscillating joints combine into the total motion of the system.

2. Formulated geometric cost models that turn the cost of moving the joints into pathlengths through the space of limb and body joint configurations. These models take into account both friction-dominated and inertia-dominated physics domains, and incorporate a notion of ``normalized average effort”, such that disparate joint motions or motions executed by disparate systems, can all be compared by how long they would take to execute at this normalized averate effort.

3. Combined our area-based net displacement model with the length-based cost model to show that optimizing locomotion efficiency for these systems follows a general maximize-area / minimize-perimeter structure.

To make these ideas more accessible to researchers, especially engineers and biologists who do not have the background to construct the tools from their mathematical descriptions, we have:

1. Released a user-friendly software package that encodes the above area/perimeter optimization paradigm. The package provides tools for specifying system properties and desired motions, generating and exporting figures that illustrate how the desired motions interact with the system dynamics, and exporting animations of the resulting motion.

2. Developed a book introducing the core geometric-mechanics topics — differential geometry and Lie group theory — to an engineering audience The core narrative in this book provides readers with a physical sense for how concepts from these fields relate to motion in the world, while a parallel narrative drops one level deeper into the mathematics, providing a stepping stone for readers into the broader geometric mechanics literature.

3. Designed an undergraduate-level multi-body dynamics class whose structure is informed by geometric mechanics, but which presents the material to students using a simpler vector-calculus language. A key benefit of this approach is that it organizes and packages features in the system dynamics so that students can re-use them across problems, ultimately letting them work with more complicated and real-world-like systems.
